intro: Haplachne pilosissima, commonly known as the silky sandmat, is a flowering plant native to arid and semi-arid regions of the southwestern United States and northern Mexico. It is characterized by its low-growing, mat-forming habit and hairy, silvery-green foliage that helps reduce water loss in harsh environments. The plant produces small, inconspicuous yellow flowers arranged in clusters, which are typically pollinated by insects. Its fibrous roots allow it to thrive in sandy soils, and it plays a role in stabilizing dunes and preventing erosion. Haplachne pilosissima is adapted to withstand extreme temperatures and limited water availability, making it a resilient species in its native habitat.
